and it absolutely is in fact there's a
few different ways that we can calculate
the direction of a sound in our brains
but
one of the most important ways is with
something called interaural
time difference so for example if a
sound is coming from directly in front
of me
it will reach both ears at the same time
and my brain
will receive that same signal from both
my ears
at the same time alternatively if the
sound is coming from off to my left
it will reach my left ear a little bit
before it reaches my right ear
and so my brain will receive a signal
from my left ear a little bit before it
receives a signal from my
right ear and your brain essentially
tries to line up the two
signals so look the left signal seems to
be slightly ahead of the right signal
which corresponds to
about 0.3 milliseconds and your brain
can actually test this hypothesis by
shifting the signals
around until all the lumps and bumps
line up with each other
and your brain interprets this 0.3
millisecond difference in timing to mean
the sound is coming from say 45 degrees
away from dead center the exact angle
would depend on the size of your head
